last_replies.filename: the last thing a trespasser sees before the cops show up

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4369139
Keep him on a short leash and anytime he loses his cool keep calm, immediate correction, and don't let him move on until he calms down. He can be rewarded with a lil longer leash and loving pets and treats when he reacts properly on the first correction. You have to do this every time, it will require patience but its is very possible to train him out of this within a couple weeks given you have a calm nature and are consistent.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4369139
Also over exposure. Worse thing people do with aggro dogs is get scared/anxious to take them for walks so they only take them out once or twice a day. So over expose your puppy to walks, make him take walks when he is chilling and calm not just when hes anxious to go outside and begging for it. Take him for 4 to 5 walks a day and eventually crowded walks and strangers walking up to him won't be such a rare shock.

>Type and size of animal

Waxy Leafed Horror!

It's plaguing our Garden.

Any ideas on this herbal vermin?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: See if it has a main root stem, poke a hole down the middle, pour some dry KNO3 (potassium nitrate) on it, sold as stump remover. Or you could heat it, I kill giant hogweed around here with a red hot glowing wire (steel wire and a car battery). I push it down into the root stem, with gloves on, phototoxic sap isn't fun.

last_replies.com:
>>4367611
The concept of a "nanny dog" originates from Peter Pan. The story featured a dog called Nana who worked as a nanny. Nana was a Newfoundland dog.

The idea that pitbulls are nanny dogs originates from a 1971 New York Times article with the headline "A Breed That Came Up the Hard Way". A spokesman for a Staffordshire Bull Terrier club was talking about that breed, and she claimed they're known as "nursemaid dogs". This claim was later repeated and distorted until it evolved into its current form.

threads.com:
Fellow mammals, this is the new invertebrate thread
I saw a thread a while back talking about everything invertebrate wise, and it seemed like a cool subject to talk about the world of bugs
I’ll start us off with this thread about solitary bees of California since it is my realm of “expertise” to kick us off
But of course, for any other entomology frens that also breathes this, chime in and talk about the bugs you find interesting or anything relating to invertebrates

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4369089
Exactly what are solitary bees?
You may have heard the bee poster child’s like honeybees and bumblebees
These bees are perfect examples of what you would call eusocial bees, meaning they’re bees that work together in a hive supporting a queen bee
You can imagine this as a communist dystopia of a sort, all the workers bowing down to one rule
Solitary bees, on the other hand, sounds and behave very similarly to eusocial bees, but not quite
Solitary bees are what I call them a one (wo)man army, because solitary bees, the ones doing all the carry in terms of foraging and reproduction, are all female bees who construct very intricate nests with brood cells to lay their eggs on
Many of these solitary bees roam alone building their own nest on abandoned ground cavities or trees
There has been evidence of solitary bees communing to one nest, but they live apart from each other
Think of it as an apartment building, where multiple tenants live together but don’t want to deal with each other
While this exist, almost all solitary bees work alone and manage their own nests
Op pic btw is a leaf cutter bee, since bees in this genus solely collect pollen in their abdomen, Megachile
This pic is a ground digger bee, or Habropoda

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4369092
In burgerland, there exist around 6k bee species, 1/3 of those bees exist and are native to California
While California has its ups and down (politically mainly), it’s hard to argue against the fact that it is a biodiversity hotspot of not just bugs, but also plants and vertebrates
And in these areas, especially coastal habitats, exist a vast array of solitary bees, from time fly sized ones to big chunky ones
Just like flowers, these bees emerge during the spring time, and take about 2-3 weeks to complete a nest
A completed nest means a nest with finished built cells with provisions ready for the larvae
A single solitary bee makes its foraging trip almost all morning and early afternoon, and only feeds around the afternoon, as soon as it emerges from their nest
Only females actually pollinate plants, and males in this case only exist to fuck as many bees
Although there is some evidence of males pollinating plants,90% of the time they find mates

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4369099
Wild bees pollinate about 80% of the worlds flowering plants, as well as crop fields
They account to about $10 billion worth of pollination services each year, and they do it for free
Some them are specialized to pollinate particular flowers and others are more generalized
What I find these fellas interesting is just how much diversity there is around the world, especially the way they build their nests
Some build their nests on sands and the ground, others make essentially mud huts, others nest on snailshells, and some make cavities on trees and bark
The fact that these guys do this all around is pretty cool, since I wasn’t aware of this when I started my grad work years ago

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4369104
With these bees present also comes with natural predators
Some noticeable predators, aside birds, revolve in the microbio world
Mites, funguses and some bacteria are dangerous for nest builders by essentially either killing the eggs or adult female
Aside that, also exist an entire family of cleptoparisitic bees
Just like cuckoo birds, these cuckoo bees invade nest cavities and replace the host eggs with their own
These guys are pretty vicious, in terms of invading and attacks
Even though they have no pollination abilities, they are a good indicator in telling us how well local bees are faring
Basically, if you find a few parasitic bees on a sample site, it would indicate a healthy solitary bee population in the vicinity
Pic related is a common parasitic bee, Sphecodes

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4369117
I would like to end this spiel by saying just like many insects from around the world, while it seems we know a lot, solitary bees are pretty understudied such as male bees role in pollination, parasitic bees adaptions to invade, and many more
They are very charismatic insects, because so many of them exist, and imo, they’re really cute
Just so you know I’m not pulling anything out of my ass, a lot of what I said is from this book pic related
It’s really detailed on discussing solitary bees and the way they live and behave in case anyone likes bees as much as I do

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
E.V.O.: The Theory of Evolution is a Japanese elusive RPG for the NEC PC-9801 home computer. It was devolved by Almanic and published by Enix in 1990. The directer, Takashi Yoneda, is a science fiction author. He wanted to make a game that gave the player perspective on their place in the universe. This was the end result.

In E.V.O. you play as Gaia's chosen hero, an at first unremarkable creature that you are able to evolve over time into the peak life form. Your goal is to guide life in the right direction as the Devil tries to destroy it by tampering with evolution. The Devil has already tampered with the evolution of the surrounding planets, causing them to become lifeless. There is still some life on the moon, and how these aliens interacted with earth in the past and present is also a key plot point. Speculative evolution is even implemented in the later parts of the game.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
The actual combat system is passable, but the way you level up is interesting. There are no levels in the traditional sense, as you instead use your cumulative exp to spec into different stats individually. Once a stat is maxed out you are given the option to evolve. Enemies evolve at the same pace as you, so make sure to have a balanced character. Each new creature you evolve into has unique moves in combat and over world hazard resistances. It is also possible to evolve into an evolutionary dead end. Doing this is one of the ways to get a bad ending, which there are many of. These endings are just meant to be jokes, and you are not penalized for getting them. The manual even encourages you to find them all.

Overall I'd say that it's a "I watched a let's play" out of 10. The game is a very grind heavy for little game play substance. The combat is even more primitive than the original Dragon Quest. Its a shame really, because the plot and level system is something else. If it looked fun I'd be more eager to figure out how to emulate it, but as is the plot and themes are really what holds it up. It's a real shame then that the plot was butchered in the SNES reimagining E.V.O.: Search for Eden.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: Do hermit crabs make good pets?
threads.com: I heard they are kind of hard to take care of because they tend to stress out apparently and most of the ones kept as pets don't usually live past like a year despite the animal can live to like 10-15 years in the wild. Do you have to give them larger shells as they grow older?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4367892
>Make sure that the substrate is at least 3x the height of the crab + shell, in depth.
This will provide plenty of depth for burrowing to molt. Otherwise they will feel insecure which stresses them. Once you have your substrate in place, use a chopstick against the glass to make a tiny borehole all the way down to the bottom, then carefully pull it out. Monitor this borehole for the first month after you put the substrate in. If water pools at the bottom, your crabs are in danger of a burrow collapse leading to drowning. To prevent that from happening in that case, you'll need to get water out. Venting your crabitat takes forever, but if there is very little water pooling it's the safest way to get it out. If there is a lot of water you want to take out the substrate, dump the water separately, and try again.


>When you dampen the substrate use your saltwater mix to prevent mold growing in it.
I went through a couple of complete substrate changes in a few months before I figured this out. This really stressed the crabs out, and you may risk injuring one if it is molting when you realize you need to change it. Even if it survives you pulling it out during a molt, the other crabs may decide to kill and eat it while its exoskeleton is still soft. I personally have only sand as the substrate, and organic material stays on top so it can be easily cleaned out. I haven't had a mold problem since I figured this out, and it's been a couple of years now.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4367894
>You will need two water dishes, and a good food surface.
One water dish is for fresh water, and one is for salt water. The water dishes need to be deep enough to wade in but still allow the crab to climb out with slippery claws. They will drink the fresh water. They will bathe in both. They will also keep a mixture in their shells to keep themselves from drying out (they do have gills). You won't need to bathe them, or force them in, they will handle it all on their own. Change the waters with a new batch of fresh and salt water once a week, but top them both off every day with fresh water alone. If you top off with salt water everyday it will become too salty as the water evaporates and leaves salt behind. For the food dish I use a cleaned and boiled clam shell.
>Before you put a crab in, let it bathe itself in a separate container
This will allow it to be introduced to the other crabs with less of a foreign smell. You'll want to have additional fresh/salt water dishes for this, and allow the crab access to them (but not the crabitat) overnight. The next day you can place the crab in the crabitat. The existing tank mates will still be wary of the newcomer, but are not likely to attack it if there are enough hiding places and it doesn't smell like it just came from some foreign territory.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4367902
>Add enough places on the surface to hide from the light in a hurry
They need some place to run to away from the light when they see movement, to feel safe. They can burrow fast, but they can scurry away much faster. Please note that if they are not feeling well or are stressed they WILL fight over hiding places so have enough for everyone to have their own. This is critical when introducing a new member to the crabitat if you don't want them to tear each other apart limb by limb.
>Dampen the substrate in a separate container by mixing it with little pours of water at a time.
Some people like to water the substrate from above, but this gets tedious and leads to over watering. Mix it all beforehand and make sure your aquarium stays closed. This lets you get the substrate wet enough to hold its shape (prevents collapsing burrows) but also allows you to scoop it into the aquarium leaving any excess water behind (prevents drowning). You don't want to drown your crabs when it rains in your aquarium. Not only for obvious reasons, but as noted itt they will burrow for weeks at a time. Are they still alive down there? If you dig them up you may injure them. You'll only know when your crabitat starts to smell of rotten fish. Having all of the substrate wet will also allow you to setup a self-sustaining water cycle.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4367903
>Armadillidiidae make wonderful tank mates
You want a population of at least 20 individuals, 40 is better. This will prevent inbreeding, as some will get eaten by the crabs. During the day they will hide under whatever is in the tank, and at night they will come out to feed. They eat organic material on the surface, to include leftover food and crab poo. This will help keep your tank very clean.

Also a couple of notes for
>>4367902
You do have to treat both the fresh and saltwater before you give them to the crabs. You want treatment for chlorine, chloramine, and heavy metals.
Also, my food surface is a cleaned out and boiled clam half-shell. It just sits on the sand. The crabs mostly keep the food in, and the Armadillidiidae will eat the little bits that get out. Also, you will see the tiny young Armadillidiidae here easiest, so you'll know if your population is reproducing.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4367910
And just a bit more to add:
Feed the daily, no more than they would usually eat overnight. Sometimes they will eat it all (especially after a molt), so put a pinch more in the next evening. If you have food in there for 3 or 4 days it will get moldy. This is why you feed them less, more often (and also why you have the feeding surface).

Talk to your crabs when you are feeding them or maintaining their waters. Research has shown crabs can recognize individual people by their voice, but not by sight. After a while they will get to know you, and instead of running away to hide when you are nearby, if you talk they will only go in their shells when they see movement, or may just freeze in place and watch you.

We had a beagle show up on our doorstep, freezing and malnourished without a collar (though it looks like he had one). I'd imagine he was a hunting dog considering where I live. We have had plenty of 'em through our property at various times.

>Likes to trail off and gets caught on scents and sounds

No nips or any aggressive nature, at least yet. He also hasn't tried to go to the bathroom inside and finds his way into the treeline to take care of business.

Do we need to get a shock collar to keep him from disappearing? He's not neutered and I'm kind of against getting it done. I know beagles like to explore but it'd be nice if I didn't have to constantly watch him outside.
